description.narrative: The project aims to create better livelihoods and gender inclusion for people working along the Development Minerals value chain in ACP Countries.

activity-description.narrative: Programme focus country. ACP-EU Development Minerals Programme: Phase II

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: Institutions in ACP countries have improved business enabling environment for gender-inclusive, operationalisation and formalisation of ASMEs along the Development Minerals value chain - Number of ACP countries with new or improved policies, laws, regulations to facilitate formalisation, gender inclusion and business development of ASMEs - Number of ASMEs that are formalised and/or access extension services through programme support - Number of ACP countries with geo-data maps created/ geo-data inventories conducted and experts trained in geodata collection and digitisation
Output 2: ASMEs have enhanced entrepreneurial skills and access to finance, technology, markets and market information; and better regulations - Number of ASMEs/ cooperatives/chambers/ associations trained in enterprise management and related technical skills demonstrating improved practices - Number of ASMEs that applied for / obtained small grants, credit or other financial products from financial institutions and other actors
Output 3: Public institutions, communities, women’s organisations and CSOs have strengthened capacity to put in place social and environmental safeguards in mining and quarrying of Development Minerals - Number of ASMEs/cooperatives, civil society groups, academia, regulators trained in mine and quarry management/number of selected participants who have developed return-to-work plans (RWPs) on environmental management, occupational safety and health, and gender inclusion - Number of training programmes with thematic relevance to Development Minerals developed and delivered by universities, colleges, training centres, business development consultancies, associations and other training entities - Number of ASME operators, community members, CSO staff, academia, regulators and local governments staff trained and implementing improved community engagement/conflict management and protection of human rights/labour/gender/child rights
Output 4: Women-owned ASMEs

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Institutions in ACP countries have improved business enabling environment for gender-inclusive, operationalisation and formalisation of ASMEs along the Development Minerals value chain - 8 ACP countries with new or improved policies, laws, regulations to facilitate formalisation, gender inclusion and business development of ASMEs - 4475 that are formalised and/or access extension services through programme support - 6 ACP countries with geodata maps created/geodata inventories conducted and experts trained in geodata collection and digitisation
Output 2: ASMEs have enhanced entrepreneurial skills and access to finance, technology, markets and market information; and better regulations - 1258 ASMEs/cooperatives/chambers/associations trained in enterprise management and related technical skills demonstrating improved practices - 60 ASMEs that applied for/obtained small grants credit or other financial products from financial institutions and other actors
Output 3: Public institutions, communities, women’s organisations and CSOs have strengthened capacity to put in place social and environmental safeguards in mining and quarrying of Development Minerals - 299 ASMEs/cooperatives, civil society groups, academia, regulators trained in mine and quarry management/number of selected participants who have developed return-to-work plans (RWPs) on environmental management, occupational safety and health, and gender inclusion - 42 training programmes with thematic relevance to the Development Minerals developed by universities, colleges, training centres, business development consultancies, associations, and other training entities - 94 ASME operators, community members, CSO staff, academia, regulators and local governments staff trained and implementing improved community engagement/conflict management and protection of human rights/labour/gender/child rights
Output 4: Women-owned ASMEs are supported to operate in the Development of Minerals value-chain - 153 wo

(Output 1 2 small grants for producing databases with digitized geo-data
Output 2 210 ASMEs/ cooperatives/chambers/ associations trained in enterprise management and related technical skills demonstrating improved practices 30 ASMEs that obtained small grants, credit or other financial products from financial institutions and other actors
Output 3 45 ASMEs/cooperatives, civil society groups, academia, regulators trained in mine and quarry management/number of selected participants who have developed return-to-work plans (RWPs) on environmental management, occupational safety and health, and gender inclusion 1 training programme with thematic relevance to Development Minerals developed and delivered by universities, colleges, training centres, business development consultancies, associations and other training entities 50 ASME operators, community members, CSO staff, academia, regulators and local governments staff trained and implementing improved community engagement/conflict management and protection of human rights/labour/gender/child rights
Output 4 20 women ASMEs/cooperatives/ associations receiving support in enterprise development, business management and related technical skills 44 staff of regulatory agencies, local governments, potential buyer companies and financial institutions trained in gender equality and women empowerment, with the application of these principles in the Development Minerals sector 18 government institutions and private sector companies with gender-responsive procurement policies and practices
Output 5 3 knowledge products produced (investor guide, handbook, and an information booklet) 338 stakeholders who have increased knowledge and positive attitude towards ASMEs and gender inclusion, affirmative procurement policies in Development Minerals because of South-South knowledge exchange activities organised on Development Minerals)

Output 1 Mineral Policy of Jamaica adopted Geo-database improved and made publicly available Mining cadastre development using Free and Open Software System (FOSS) is completed. – a grant was provided to a local public sector agency, Mines and Geology Division, for producing supporting software and hardware to enable an on- line mining cadastre. Agency applied in October 2020 and funds were disbursed in September 2021 and will be liquidated by mid year 2022. The disbursement was delayed due to issues with providing fiscal space by the local Treasury/Ministry of Finance & Planning as well as time to complete the administrative process to access the unspent funds which is to be returned to the RPs by UNDP.
Output 2 73 ASMEs/ cooperatives/chambers/ associations trained in enterprise management and related technical skills demonstrating improved practices 11 ASMEs and other institutions received small grants (processing is ongoing)
Output 3 73 ASMEs/cooperatives, civil society groups, academia, regulators trained in mine and quarry management/number of selected participants who have developed return-to-work plans (RWPs) on environmental management, occupational safety and health, and gender inclusion
2 training programs with thematic relevance to Development Minerals developed and delivered by universities, colleges, training centres, business development consultancies, associations and other training entities (University of Technology’s Bachelor course and EXED Community college’s training course). Approximately 12 ASMEs are enrolled in the Bachelor, Mining and Quarry Management course at UTECH effective September 2021.
No ASME operators, community members, CSO staff, academia, regulators and local governments staff trained and implementing improved community engagement/conflict management and protection of human rights/labour/gender/child rights
Output 4 13 women ASMEs/cooperatives/ associations receiving support in enterprise development, business management and related technical skills 0 staff of regulatory agencies, local governments, potential buyer companies and financial institutions trained in gender equality and women empowerment, with the application of these principles in the Development Minerals sector 0 government institutions and private sector companies with gender-responsive procurement policies and practices
Output 5 Information packages were prepared and disseminated to 73 trainees 72 stakeholders who have increased knowledge and positive attitude towards ASMEs and gender inclusion, affirmative procurement policies in Development Minerals

Output 1 The new National Minerals Policy was passed in Parliament in March 2020 and distributed to the public and the sector in September 2020The policy was able to facilitate formalisation, gender inclusion and business development of ASMEs in the island. No geo-data maps were created/ geo-data inventories conducted and experts trained in geodata collection and digitisation.
Output 2 No ASMEs/ cooperatives/chambers/ associations trained in enterprise management and related technical skills demonstrating improved practices however, 18 ASMEs applied for small grants in June 2020 and 12 obtained grants in Quarter 3, 2020. Funds were disbursed at a cost of US$60,000, grants with a total of 208 beneficiaries. Monitoring and evaluation activities were completed on these grantees. Another call was issued in Quarter 4, October 2020 with 11 persons applying for grants (6 ASME’s and 5 projects from public sector Government agencies. Grantees received disbursement of US$60,000 in January 2021 . All grantees (6) have submitted relevant monitoring and evaluation documents. The remaining 5 projects will be liquidated by year end 2021 or by Quarter 2, 2022.
Output 3 0 ASMEs/cooperatives, civil society groups, academia, regulators trained in mine and quarry management/number of selected participants who have developed return-to-work plans (RWPs) on environmental management, occupational safety and health, and gender inclusion 0 training programs with thematic relevance to Development Minerals developed and delivered by universities, colleges, training centres, business development consultancies, associations and other training entities. Cash advances were successfully applied for by 2 responsible parties in Quarter 4 2020 however, disbursement and relevant Letters of Agreement were completed in 2021. 0 ASME operators, community members, CSO staff, academia, regulators and local governments staff trained and implementing improved community engagement/conflict management and protection of human rights/labour/gender/child rights
Output 4 3 women ASMEs/cooperatives/ associations received support in enterprise development, business management and related technical skills through small grants applied for in October 2020 and disbursed in January 2021. 0 staff of regulatory agencies, local governments, potential buyer companies and financial institutions trained in gender equality and women empowerment, with the application of these principles in the Development Minerals sector 0 government institutions and private sector companies with gender-responsive procurement policies and practices
Output 5 Business Development Training Resource Handbook/ reference document produced with emphasis on COVID-19 Approximately 150 copies of handbooks were printed and electronic flip version emailed to ASME’s in Development Minerals Sector in Quarter 4, 2020 and was officially handed over by the UNDP to the Mining and Quarrying Association. 100 stakeholders who have increased knowledge and positive attitude towards ASMEs and gender inclusion, affirmative procurement policies in Development Minerals

One (1) Online Mining Cadastre was launched on March 11th in Jamaica with over 70 stakeholders in attendance. The cadastre will be officially handed over from The Programme to MGD, Ministry of Transport & Mining in April 2022.
The Cadastre was developed using FOSS (Free and Open Software System) by the consultants - Compet-Terra KfT.
